docs.text: Development Environment This article describes how to set up various development environments and tools for working with computational physics. Windows Subsystem For Linux 2 Windows has built-in software to allow running of Linux operating systems within windows. This may be preferable over a full install for learning and experimenting with Linux. Keep in mind that performance within this subsystem is low, and it should not be used for intensive programs such as Vivado. Commands are to be executed in Powershell as Administrator, you must be running Windows 10 Version 1903 or higher dism.exe /online /enable-feature /featurename:Microsoft-Windows-Subsystem-Linux /all /norestart dism.exe /online /enable-feature /featurename:VirtualMachinePlatform /all /norestart Restart your computer (actually click restart, shutting down will not work). Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "https://wslstorestorage.blob.core.windows.net/wslblob/wsl_update_x64.msi" -Outfile ~\Downloads\wsl_update_x64.msi ~\Downloads\wsl_update_x64.msi Follow onscreen instructions to install the WSL kernel. wsl --set-default-version 2 Open the Microsoft Store and install your preferred Linux Distribution (Ubuntu and Debian are the best supported in WSL). If you would like to run graphical applications, you will need an X server. Install VcXsrv to the default path, then run & 'C:\Program Files\VcXsrv\xlaunch.exe' Use the default settings for the first two pages. On the third page, uncheck Native opengl. In your Linux subsystem, create an environment variable to allow programs to use the X server echo 'export DISPLAY=:0' >> ~/.bashrc C/C++ Compilers and Build tools Arch Linux sudo pacman -Syu base-devel Ubuntu sudo apt install build-essential manpages-dev MacOS Head to Apple Developer Downloads , download and install the latest (non-beta) "Command Line Tools for Xcode". CERN Root Data Analysis Framework Arch Linux sudo pacman -Syu root Ubuntu sudo snap install root-framework If you would like to run root without sandboxing from snap , then snap run root-framework MacOS Head to Apple Developer Downloads , download and install the latest (non-beta) "Command Line Tools for Xcode". You do not need to install the Xcode app. /bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)" brew install root Vivado It is recommended that you install all major versions if you have space on your disk. Red Pitaya is currently being developed on Vivado 2019.2 if you only have space for a single Viviado version. Arch Linux Make sure your system locale is set to en_US.UTF-8 . git clone https://aur.archlinux.org/vivado.git cd vivado makepkg -si mkdir -p ~/.local/bin echo '#!/bin/sh\nuname -m' > ~/.local/bin/arch For Vitis_HLS 2020.2, a patch is needed to fix a bug that prevents it from running. Find Vitis_HLS/2020.2/common/scripts/autopilot_init.tcl and edit line 40 from ----%r&-'%rl%&n$&lt'v-= to ----%r&-'%rl%&n$&lt'v-> . Ubuntu / Windows Download Xilinx Unified/Web Installer and follow the on-screen instructions to install Vivado, Vitis, as well as support packages for the boards you intend to work on (you can change this later if you're unsure). Text Editors Here's a list of popular text editors and a brief description. You should use your distro's package manager to install these Visual Studio Code - Feature rich text editor with syntax highlighting and linting for nearly every type of file through extensions. Vim - Ancient text editor that you will spend 2 minutes trying to exit your first time using it. Neovim - Vim but actually usable. Emacs - Imagine like, keyboard shortcuts, but in Einstein notation. Arch Linux Arch is a Linux distribution focused on user controlled maintainence and system configuration. If you are not interested in configuring your own Linux system, other distros such as Ubuntu, Debian, and Fedora are configured by their respective parent companies. This is a supplement to the Official Installation Guide that explains the impact of various decisions you may make during the install process. The first major decision will be partitioning the disks. Two partitions are needed EFI System Partition (ESP - Recommended Size = 498MB): This partition contains a simple filesystem that is widely supported by most devices. We typically want a more complex filesystem for the Linux system, however these are rarely supported by most devices' firmware. Hence, a seperate partition, the ESP, is used to store applications and drivers that allow us to read and boot the Linux system. Linux System Partition (root - Recommended Size >= 100GB): This partition contains most or all of the files for the operating system. Some of the tools we will use such as Vivado and CERN Root will take a considerable amount of space, hence at least 100GB is recommended. Next, you will need to create a filesystem on each partition. Below are my recommendations for the filesystems and a brief explaination. You can look through Wikipedia if you would like a comparison of filesystems. ESP : FAT32 - Universally supported, allows the system to boot from basically any system capable of loading an EFI, uboot, or coreboot. The ESP filesystem should be mounted at /boot if you would like all files required for booting to be stored in the ESP. root : BTRFS - A stable filesystem with checksumming to ensure silent corruption is impossible. It also supports snapshotting and other backup features which is important for a development environment. Supports transparent filesystem compression and encryption. In order to boot the system, you have a few options. rEFInd (Recommended): A user-friendly bootloader that has an automated install process and requires no additional configuration. rEFInd will automatically detect operating systems available to your system, and handle creating the appropriate paramaters for loading these systems. Grub : A feature-rich bootloader that supports encryption, btrfs snapshot recovery, among other features. However, grub does not auto-detect operating systems at boot time, nor is it able to automatically create parameters to boot. These will need to be configured using a script grub-mkconfig each time you change your system configuration. UEFI Loader (Not Recommended): If you're using a personal computer built in the last couple of decades, chances are your system will have a built-in bootloader. This can be configured using efibootmgr to directly load a Linux operating system from the vmlinuz image. Follow the official installation guide and associated subpages for decisions on other system components, such as desktop environments, shells, etc... These are mostly up to your preference. Linux on T2 Macbooks (2018 and Newer) If you would like to run Linux natively on Macbooks, you will need A patched kernel with SMC and wifi drivers The T2 ARM coprocessor BCE drivers Broadcom Wifi firmware from MacOS Mojave or older And optionally Touchbar and Ambient Light Sensor drivers Fan controller Guides are currently available on T2Linux . I will write a guide that doesn't require any external connections or dongles soon.

docs.text: Linear Algebra This page is a WIP. Vectors Often in math, we have multiple variables to track for each data point. For instance, when we make 2D plots, we use horizontal and vertical coordinate \(x\) and \(y\) to represent its location. We can encode this information of a point \(P\) into a vector \[P = \begin{pmatrix} x\\ y \end{pmatrix}\] Here, the position of the numbers in the vector carries information about the coordinate it's describing. The first number describes the horizontal coordinate and the second number describes the vertical coordinate. Vectors have similar properties to standard (real) numbers. Addition, subtraction and multiplication by constants for vectors behave as one would expect \[\begin{align} \begin{pmatrix} a\\ b \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} c\\ d \end{pmatrix} &= \begin{pmatrix} a + c\\ b + d \end{pmatrix}\\ \begin{pmatrix} a\\ b \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} c\\ d \end{pmatrix} &= \begin{pmatrix} a - c\\ b - d \end{pmatrix}\\ k \begin{pmatrix} a\\ b \end{pmatrix} &= \begin{pmatrix} ka\\ kb \end{pmatrix} \end{align}\] I am demonstrating these properties with column (vertical) matrices of size two, although matrices can be any size. There are also row (horizontal) vectors. The orientation impacts the way two vectors multiply. Two vectors of equal size can be multiplied together to yield a number. This is called the inner product. \[\begin{pmatrix} a & b \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} c\\ d \end{pmatrix} = ac + bd \] Matrices Just like how multiple variables can be stacked in vectors, vectors can also be stacked into matrices. \[\begin{gather} \begin{pmatrix} a & c \\ b & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} e & j \\ f & k \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} ae + cf & aj + bk\\ be + df & bj + dk \end{pmatrix}\\ \end{gather} \] Again, the matrices here are \(2 \times 2\) , but in general can be any size. docs.text: Opportunities These opportunities focus on those available to students attending U.S high schools and Universities as these are the ones I am familliar with. Feel free to suggest additions in the Discord . Research Fellowship at National Institute of Standards and Technology Award: $10,000 - $20,000 Acceptance rate: 20 - 50% Criteria: Incomming and Current Undergraduate Assist with cutting-edge research at NIST working alongside a mentor at the laboratories in either Gaithersburg, Maryland or Boulder, Colorado. The program lasts for 11 weeks over the summer. Students can work one of 6 labs: Communications Technology Laboratory (CTL), Engineering Laboratory (EL), Information Technology Laboratory (ITL), Material Measurement Laboratory (MML), NIST Center for Neutron Research (NCNR), and Physical Measurement Laboratory (PML). If you're looking for Physics related research, look into NCNR or MML. I would recommend dorming with others and looking for AirBnB or similar housing to reduce costs. Apply for NIST Gaithersburg or NIST Boulder . Research Experience for Undergraduates Award: ~$5,000 Acceptance rate: Varies Criteria: Undergraduate This is a collection of programs offered by various research universities to allow students to visit and conduct research with professors. Use the NSF tool to search for an REU or browse by subject. REUs are useful for building connections and networking; building connections a university greatly improves your success rate in applying to their graduate program. Oak Ridge National Labs Internship Award: Varies Acceptance rate: Varies Criteria: Highschool - Graduate Various internship programs at ORNL in Tennessee focused on physics and math education. Contains many options for fundamental physics experimental research for undergraduates. Goldwater Scholarship Award: $7,500 - $15,000 Acceptance rate: ~30% Criteria: 2nd or 3rd year Undergraduate Research Scholarship to award undergraduates for excellence in academics. Speak to your university's office of nationally competitive awards to apply. The application includes a personal statement about your experiences and goals, as well as a research proposal or a write-up of previous research. Astronaut Scholarship Award: $15,000 (per year awarded) Acceptance rate: 20-30% Criteria: 2nd or 3rd year Undergraduate Despite its name, this is not a scholarship for Astronauts. It is a competitive research scholarship similar to Goldwater. Speak to your university's office of nationally competitive awards to apply. Application requires an academic resume and a personal statement. National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship Award: $138,000 Acceptance rate: 16% Criteria: Sciences Major, 4th year Undergrad - 1st year Graduate Research Fellowship for students pursuing PhD in a Sciences field. Very high value scholarship, especially given the relatively high acceptance rate. Refrence letters required. Apply prior to applying to grad schools in October, the GRFP award will be announced in around March - April, which may be early enough to leverage the GRFP to gain admissions into wait-listed graduate schools. National Merit Scholarship Award: $2500 + Full ride to many Universities Acceptance rate: 1.5% Criteria: High School Students have the opportunity to take the PSAT during the third year of high school. The top 8000 scores are considered for the National Merit Scholarship. While the amount awarded is relatively small, many schools will offer full rides (tuition + room) for students named National Merit Finalists.

docs.text: Quantum Mechanics Construction of Quantum Mechanics The Hamiltionain for a particle in a scalar potential $V(x) as constructed in [classical mechanics] is \[\mathcal{H} = \frac{p^2}{2m} + V(x)\] In Quantum Mechanics, we treat the Hamiltonian as some linear operator \(\hat{\mathcal{H}}\) that acts on a state \(\psi(x)\) \[\hat{\mathcal{H}} \psi(x) \equiv \left(\frac{\hat{p}^2}{2m} + V(x)\right) \psi(x)\] Where \(\hat p\) is the operator associated with momentum which we will soon determine. Suppose we have a free particle where \(V(x) = 0\) . Recall that the Hamiltonian is a [conserved quantity], in the operator formulation \[\left(\frac{\hat{p}^2}{2m}\right) \psi(x) = E \psi(x)\] This is a simple second order ODE with the solution \[\psi(x) = \exp\left(\frac{i\hat p x}{\hbar}\right)\]
